head.title: A Three-Dimensional Nano-web Scaffold of Ferroelectric Beta-PVDF Fibers for Lithium Metal Plating and Stripping | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: A Three-Dimensional Nano-web Scaffold of Ferroelectric Beta-PVDF Fibers for Lithium Metal Plating and Stripping

Lithium metal has been considered as an anode material to improve energy densities of lithium chemistry-based rechargeable batteries (that is to say, lithium metal batteries or LMBs). Higher capacities and cell voltages are ensured by replacing practically used anode materials such as graphite with lithium metal. However, lithium metal as the LMB anode material has been challenged by its dendritic growth, electrolyte decomposition on its fresh surface, and its serious volumetric change. To address the problems of lithium metal anodes, herein, we guided and facilitated lithium ion transport along a spontaneously polarized and highly dielectric material. A three-dimensional web of nanodiameter fibers of ferroelectric beta-phase polyvinylidene fluoride (beta-PVDF) was loaded on a copper foil by electrospinning (PVDF#Cu). The electric field applied between the nozzle and target copper foil forced the dipoles of PVDF to be oriented centro-asymmetrically and then the beta structure induced ferroelectric polarization. Three-fold benefits of the ferroelectric nano-web architecture guaranteed the plating/stripping reversibility especially at high rates: (1) three-dimensional scaffold to accommodate the volume change of lithium metal during plating and stripping, (2) electrolyte channels between fibers to allow lithium ions to move, and (3) ferroelectrically polarized or negatively charged surface of beta-PVDF fibers to encourage lithium ion hopping along the surface. Resultantly, the beta-PVDF web architecture drove dense and integrated growth of lithium metal within its structure. The kinetic benefit expected from the ferroelectric lithium ion transport of beta-PVDF as well as the porous architecture of PVDF#Cu was realized in a cell of LFP as a cathode and lithium-plated PVDF#Cu as an anode. Excellent plating/stripping reversibility along repeated cycles was successfully demonstrated in the cell even at a high current such as 2.3 mA cm–2, which was not obtained by the nonferroelectric polymer layer.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

img.alt: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

div.p:
Lithium metal has been considered as an anode material to improve energy densities of lithium chemistry-based rechargeable batteries (that is to say, lithium metal batteries or LMBs). Higher capacities and cell voltages are ensured by replacing practically used anode materials such as graphite with lithium metal. However, lithium metal as the LMB anode material has been challenged by its dendritic growth, electrolyte decomposition on its fresh surface, and its serious volumetric change. To address the problems of lithium metal anodes, herein, we guided and facilitated lithium ion transport along a spontaneously polarized and highly dielectric material. A three-dimensional web of nanodiameter fibers of ferroelectric beta-phase polyvinylidene fluoride (beta-PVDF) was loaded on a copper foil by electrospinning (PVDF#Cu). The electric field applied between the nozzle and target copper foil forced the dipoles of PVDF to be oriented centro-asymmetrically and then the beta structure induced ferroelectric polarization. Three-fold benefits of the ferroelectric nano-web architecture guaranteed the plating/stripping reversibility especially at high rates: (1) three-dimensional scaffold to accommodate the volume change of lithium metal during plating and stripping, (2) electrolyte channels between fibers to allow lithium ions to move, and (3) ferroelectrically polarized or negatively charged surface of beta-PVDF fibers to encourage lithium ion hopping along the surface. Resultantly, the beta-PVDF web architecture drove dense and integrated growth of lithium metal within its structure. The kinetic benefit expected from the ferroelectric lithium ion transport of beta-PVDF as well as the porous architecture of PVDF#Cu was realized in a cell of LFP as a cathode and lithium-plated PVDF#Cu as an anode. Excellent plating/stripping reversibility along repeated cycles was successfully demonstrated in the cell even at a high current such as 2.3 mA cm
–2
, which was not obtained by the nonferroelectric polymer layer.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Recently, lithium metal anodes have attracted interests for realizing high-energy-density rechargeable batteries. Lithium is able to deliver such a high capacity of up to 3860 mAh g
–1
at a more negative potential (−3.04 V versus standard hydrogen electrodes), having a low gravimetric density (0.534 g cm
–3
).
(1−4)
However, uneven Li ion fluxes during repeated plating and stripping cycles form heterogeneous Li deposition, resulting in uncontrollable dendrite growth.
(5−7)
The growth of these dendrites increases the surface area of the Li metal anode and isolates the Li particles. Furthermore, the morphology of the dendrites results in a large electrode–electrolyte interface, which promotes the formation of a solid electrolyte-interphase (SEI) layer on the Li surface. This leads to continuous electrolyte consumption and, eventually, degradation of the battery’s performance during repeated cycles.
(8−10)

Considerable efforts have been devoted to addressing these issues.
(11−13)
Physical layers were placed on current collectors or lithium metal foils. Lithium was plated less dendritically between the protective layer and current collector. Various materials were used for the protective layer, including two-dimensional materials, functional polymer films, and ceramic materials.
(14−18)
Alternatively, lithiophilic materials and electrolyte additives were employed to encourage homogeneous nucleation of lithium metal over current collectors.
(19−22)
As another approach, the flat geometry of current collectors or lithium metal foils was replaced by a three-dimensional (3D) structure to provide space for deposited lithium metal mass.
(23−26)
Lithium growth was limited within voids and pores of 3D scaffolds without serious electrode volume change between plating and stripping. However, it has been still difficult to guarantee the reversibility of lithium plating/stripping electrochemistry especially at current densities higher than 2 mA cm
–2
.
(27)

Ferroelectric polarization was exploited to suppress the dendritic growth of lithium metal. A thin film of beta-phase polyvinylidene difluoride (beta-PVDF) was laminated on lithium metal foil for dendrite-free lithium deposition.
(28)
The ferroelectric nature of beta-phase PVDF is developed by its atomically aligned structure along the backbone axis. Fluorine is located on one side of the axis, while hydrogen is placed on the other side. Therefore, beta-phase PVDF is polarized in the direction perpendicular to the polymer backbone axis. The aligned negative charges on the fluorine side provide (1) affinity to lithium cations and (2) lithium ion diffusion highway along which the lithium ion hops between fluorine sites. These benefits obtained from the ferroelectric nature of beta-PVDF were also realized when the beta-PVDF was used as a binder for lithium titanate anode and lithium iron phosphate cathode of lithium ion batteries.
(29)
The autonomous polarization of beta-PVDF resulting in metallicity improved charge transfer kinetics of lithium metal plating (
Figure S1
). Even if lithium ion movement was more facilitated along PVDF than other polymers used as mechanically protective layers, however, the reversibility of lithium metal plating and stripping was still not fully guaranteed at high currents.
(28)
Reversible lithium plating/stripping only at a limited current density (0.4 mA cm
–2
) in a full cell was successfully demonstrated in the previous ferroelectricity-related work (indicated by blue square in
Figure S2
).

In this work, we present a nano-web of ferroelectric beta-phase PVDF fibers on copper foil as a three-dimensional scaffold platform for lithium plating and stripping. The web structure, instead of a thin solid film, was designed to (1) allow lithium ion transport to an electrode via diffusion through electrolyte channels between PVDF fibers and ferroelectrically facilitated hopping along the fluorine side of PVDF and (2) provide volume for lithium metal deposits growing along PVDF fibers.
(28)
This three-dimensional web-like structure successfully suppressed the dendritic growth of lithium metal and therefore provided lithium metal plating/stripping reversibility even at high currents such as 2.3 mA cm
–2
(indicated by red star in
Figure S2
).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The PVDF web was fabricated using the typical electrospinning method. The polymer solutions were prepared with 10 wt % PVDF (KF1100, Kureha) and a mixed solvent (DMF/THF = 7/3 by weight). A syringe with a 25-gauge metal needle was connected to the electrospinning machine (ESR200R2, NanoNC). The process was conducted with a distance of 15 cm between the needle tip and the ground (copper current collector), an applied voltage of 15.0 kV, and an injection speed of 0.5 mL h
–1
. The PVDF mat was then vacuum-dried overnight at 70 °C.

The SEM measurements were conducted using a Hitachi S-4800. The FT-IR spectra of the PVDF fiber were recorded using a Varian 670-IR spectrometer. Galvanostatic measurements of the electrospun PVDF electrode were taken using a cycle tester (WonaTech WBCS 300). To examine the morphological changes in the PVDF mat electrode at different lithiated states, the coin cells in specific states were rinsed with DMC to remove the electrolyte. The PVDF electrode was transferred from the glove box for SEM measurement using an SEM holder to avoid exposure to air.

The electrochemical performances of the symmetric and full cells were measured using a 2032-type coin cell. The coin cell was assembled in an argon-filled glove box. For the symmetric battery test, the coin cell was assembled using electrospun PVDF on Cu and Li metals as the working and reference electrodes, respectively. Electrochemical measurements were taken at voltages. The carbonate electrolyte consisted of 1 M LiPF
6
in ethylene carbonate and dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC, 3/7, v/v) with 3% mass ratio of fluoroethylene carbonate.

For the full battery test, the cathode electrode was prepared by spreading a viscous slurry of the cathode material (LiFePO
4
, Sud-Chemie), conducting agent, and PVDF binder at a weight ratio of 8:1:1 on an Al foil current collector with a loading density of 2.3 mAh cm
–2
. The full cell with Cu and PVDF electrodes was then assembled using this cathode. The electrolyte was the same as that in the half-cell test (1 M LiFP
6
in EC/DMC with 3 wt % FEC). The electrochemical performance of the full cell was tested over a cut-off voltage range of 2.0–3.8 V at a rate of 0.1–5.0 C.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
A three-dimensional web of nanodiameter fibers of ferroelectric beta-PVDF was loaded on a copper foil by electrospinning (
Figure
1
a).
(28,30)
The 54 μm-thick nano-web layer (porosity, 98.6%) of fibers with a diameter of ∼500 nm was obtained (
Figure
1
b,c and
Figures S3 and S4
). A needle, through which a solution of PVDF was injected, was positively biased, while a copper foil target was grounded (+15 kV on the needle versus the copper foil target). The electric field was expected to force the dipoles of PVDF to be oriented to the same direction so that the ferroelectric beta structure is developed with hydrogen and fluorine atoms aligned respectively (
Figure
1
d).
(29,31,32)
The beta phase of the as-electrospun PVDF was confirmed by the infrared absorption peaks at 840, 1071, 1275, and 1431 cm
–1
, responsible for the corresponding crystalline phase (
Figure
1
e).
(33)
The high-intensity peaks at 1404, 1183, and 880 cm
–1
are read as the chemical formula information of PVDF (not depending on its phase) for CH
2
wagging, CF
2
stretching, and C–C skeleton vibration, respectively. The PVDF web electrode exhibited no electrochemical reactions between 0 and 1.2 V versus Li/Li
+
in carbonate electrolytes (
Figures S5 and S6
). As another benefit obtained by using electrospinning, the electrostatically attractive interaction between the positively charged hydrogen side of PVDF fiber and the negatively charged (earthed) copper foil was expected to guarantee the strong adhesion of the three-dimensional scaffold to the current collector.

div.p: Figure 1. 3D-web PVDF scaffold electrode. (a) Electrospinning of PVDF on a copper current collector. (b, c) SEM images of the 3D-web PVDF scaffold electrode: top and cross-sectional views for (d) and (e), respectively. (d) Ferroelectric PVDF fiber. (e) Infrared spectrum of beta-phase PVDF. The peaks indicating the beta phase are indicated by red dots.

div.div:
As a preliminary test to investigate how lithium metal is electrodeposited on the beta-PVDF web scaffold, 2 mAh cm
–2
lithium metal was plated on the beta-PVDF web electrode (PVDF#Cu) and a bare copper foil electrode as its control. The dendritic growth of lithium metal was not observed at 0.5 mA cm
–2
even on the bare copper electrode (in the absence of ferroelectric PVDF web;
Figure
2
a). As the current densities increased to 1.0 and 3.0 mA cm
–2
, however, the dendrites were clearly observed with their thickness increasing in the absence of PVDF web from the top and cross-sectional views (
Figure
2
b,c). In the presence of a PVDF layer, on the other hand, it was difficult to observe electrode thickness change and the dendritic feature of lithium metal even at the highest rate of this work, 3.0 mA cm
–2
(
Figure
2
d–f). Lithium metal was grown within the three-dimensional web structure.

div.p:
Figure 2. Morphology of lithium metal deposited on the beta-PVDF-laminating copper (PVDF#Cu) and a bare copper (Cu). Lithium metal (2 mAh cm
–2
) was plated on the electrodes at three different current densities (0.5, 1.0, and 3.0 mA cm
–2
from the left) with a lithium metal foil as the counter electrode. Top and cross-sectional views of scanning electron microscopy images are presented on the left and right, respectively. Scale bars, 20 μm. (a–c) PVDF#Cu. (d–f) Cu.

div.div:
No dendritic feature on the top view of PVDF#Cu indicates that lithium metal grew less dendritically or more densely within the web of beta-PVDF fibers than on bare copper foils. It was easily expected that the void volume in the fibrous skeleton of the web accommodated the volume increase of lithium metal. The void volume of PVDF layer (0.0053 cm
3
void
/cm
2
electrode
) was larger than the volume of 2 mAh cm
–2
lithium metal plated on bare coppers (0.0018 cm
3
Li
/cm
2
electrode
at 0.5 mA cm
–2
; 0.0023 cm
3
Li
/cm
2
electrode
at 1.0 mA cm
–2
; 0.0026 cm
3
Li
/cm
2
electrode
at 3.0 mA cm
–2
). More interestingly, a density comparison of plated lithium metal between bare copper and PVDF#Cu drove us to consider the ferroelectric effect of the beta-PVDF fibers. From their top and cross-sectional views, the bare copper foils showed dendritic and flake-like features, while a continuous phase between fibers was developed in the PVDF#Cu (
Figure
2
). The apparent density of lithium metal estimated from the thickness was 0.08 in the PVDF nano-web when lithium metal was deposited at 1.0 mA cm
–2
. This value is much lower than the 0.58 porosity of lithium metal dendritically grown on a bare copper at the same current (c.f., porosity = 0.46 at 0.5 mA cm
–2
and 0.63 at 3 mA cm
–2
on the bare coppers). Such a densely grown lithium metal was not obtained when the same nano-web structure of a nonferroelectric polymer was employed (lithium metal porosity in the presence of polyacrylonitrile nano-web or PAN#Cu = 0.54 at 1 mA cm
–2
; described below in detail). We can conclude that lithium metal was very densely grown on the ferroelectric PVDF#Cu and the high density of plated lithium metal was not obtained only by the mechanical suppression of dendritic growth by the polymer film. Therefore, we suggest that there is a possibility that the ferroelectric nature of beta-PVDF let lithium metal grow along the surface of PVDF by suppressing its dendritic growth.

To verify the ferroelectric effects, the ferroelectric beta-PVDF was compared with polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as a nonferroelectric polymer.
(34)
A web electrode of PAN fibers was electrospun to a copper foil (PAN#Cu) to have its fiber diameter identical to that of the PVDF fiber and the same thickness as the PVDF web layer. Up to 5 mAh cm
–2
(equivalent to 1.3 mg Li cm
–2
) lithium metal was accommodated within the PAN web structure (red box below in
Figure
3
a). Lithium metal dendrites were observed between PAN fibers. From 7.5 mAh cm
–2
(1.9 mg Li cm
–2
), however, lithium metal protruded from the nonferroelectric PAN scaffold layer (orange below). Interestingly, on the other hand, the PVDF#Cu seemed to have more space within its structure. Empty voids were clearly observed up to 7.5 mAh cm
–2
(red and orange above) in the ferroelectric PVDF#Cu, while the nonferroelectric PAN#Cu structure was fully filled out by lithium metal threads even at 5.0 mAh cm
–2
(red below). The PVDF#Cu structure was saturated with lithium metal between 10 and 12.5 mAh cm
–2
(2.6 and 3.2 mg Li cm
–2
, respectively; green and blue above). At 15 mAh cm
–2
(3.9 mg Li cm
–2
; purple above), finally, it was difficult to find the PVDF fibers because the surface of the PVDF#Cu was fully covered by lithium metal deposits. The densely and smoothly grown lithium metal deposit was confirmed in the PVDF#Cu from its cross-sectional view at 7.5 mAh cm
–2
, which is the current density at which dendrite agglomerates were found in the PAN#Cu (
Figure
3
b).

From the visual examination of morphologies of lithium metal deposited on three-dimensional web scaffold electrodes along an increasing deposit amount, we concluded that lithium metal grew denser or less dendritic in the ferroelectric PVDF#Cu than in the nonferroelectric PAN#Cu. By a simple calculation based on the true density of lithium metal, the minimum thickness of lithium metal deposits at a given capacity was estimated. If the void of PVDF#Cu was fully filled by dense lithium metal at 10 mAh cm
–2
, then the porosity of the three-dimensional scaffolds (PVDF#Cu and PAN#Cu) would be ∼0.9 (49/54 μm where 49 μm is the thickness of dense lithium metal plated at 10 mAh cm
–2
). The value of porosity was considered to be reasonable because it was also estimated to be 0.985 from the mass and thickness of PVDF fibers loaded on copper foil. Unlike the PVDF#Cu, the PAN#Cu was fully filled at ∼5 mAh cm
–2
so that the density of lithium metal grown within the PAN#Cu was estimated to be half of the true density of lithium metal. Therefore, we confirm the effect of the ferroelectric nature of beta-PVDF since the dendritic growth of lithium metal (low density) in the PAN#Cu was suppressed when the nonferroelectric polymer was replaced by the ferroelectric beta-PVDF.

Based on the lithium metal deposit investigation above, we concluded that the ferroelectric nature of beta-PVDF drives lithium metal to grow along the surface of PVDF by suppressing its dendritic growth (the schematics of
Figure
3
b). The ferroelectric situation (PVDF#Cu) is contrasted to the nonferroelectric one (PAN#Cu) where lithium dendrites are grown from the copper current collector without any specific interaction between lithium and nonferroelectric fibers (but the role of mechanical suppression is still available even in the nonferroelectric case). Moreover, the lithium metal growth along the ferroelectric surface possibly provides a kinetic benefit since the electrically conductive surface of lithium metal on PVDF#Cu increases more than that of dendrites in PAN#Cu along the plating progress.

The superior Li
+/0
reversibility on the copper current collector in the presence of beta-PVDF web layer, which was expected from the nondendritic morphology of lithium metal on it, was apparently confirmed by repeating lithium metal plating and stripping (
Figure
4
). The Coulombic efficiency (CE) of lithium metal plating/stripping was significantly improved by placing the PVDF web onto a copper foil (
Figure
4
a). More than 98% lithium metal deposit was successfully stripped from 1 mAh cm
–2
Li-plated PVDF#Cu even after 200 times repeated plating/stripping. However, the CE of a bare copper foil decreased to 90% after the initial 10 cycles and then the lithium deposit was rarely stripped after 70 cycles. The nonferroelectric PAN#Cu was inferior to the ferroelectric web even if it improved the CE of a bare copper foil due to its role as a mechanical protective layer.

div.p:
Figure 4. Lithium metal plating/stripping reversibility along repeated cycles. (a) Coulombic efficiency (CE) of PVDF#Cu∥Li and Cu∥Li. Lithium metal (1 mAh cm
–2
) was galvanostatically plated and then fully stripped repeatedly on electrodes at 1 mA cm
–2
. (b) Potential profiles of the first lithium plating of PVDF#Cu∥Li and Cu∥Li in (a). (c) Potential profiles of 2 mAh cm
–2
[email protected]
#Cu∥Li and 2 mAh cm
–2
[email protected]
∥Li along cycles. Lithium metal (2 mAh cm
–2
) was plated on PVDF#Cu or Cu in a cell having a lithium metal foil as the counter electrode. Then, the lithium metal-loaded electrode (2 mAh cm
–2
[email protected]
#Cu or 2 mAh cm
–2
[email protected]
) was transferred to a separate test cell assembled with lithium metal. Lithium metal (1 mAh cm
–2
) on the electrodes was stripped and then the same amount of lithium metal was plated repeatedly at 1 mA cm
–2
. (d) Potential profiles of the indicated cycles of (c).

div.div:
Also, the PVDF web layer decreased (1) the nucleation overpotential relevant to charge transfer kinetics of the first plating (the maximum deviation from the Nernst potential of lithium plating, 0 V
Li
or the minimum potential value; 104 mV
Li
for PVDF#Cu < 161 mV
Li
for Cu) and (2) the diffusion potential characterizing the plateau following the potential valley (59 mV
Li
for PVDF#Cu < 91 mV
Li
for Cu) (
Figure
4
b).
(19)
The improved Li
+/0
reversibility was anticipated from the easier nucleation at the first plating. The less nucleation overpotential obtained from PVDF#Cu raised the possibility of the effects of ferroelectric polarization on nucleation kinetics. The nonferroelectric PAN#Cu was more similar to the bare copper foil electrode and significantly inferior to the PVDF#Cu in terms of nucleation and diffusion overpotentials.

Lithium metal-predeposited electrodes were also tested. Lithium (2 mAh cm
–2
) was plated on electrodes of interest in cells having lithium metal as counter electrodes. Then, the lithium-loading electrode was transferred from the predeposition cell to a test cell having a lithium metal counter electrode such as
[email protected]
#Cu∥Li and
[email protected]
∥Li cells. The PVDF#Cu was superior to the bare copper electrode in terms of overpotential evolution along repeated stripping–plating cycles both at 0.5 and 1.0 mA cm
–2
(
Figure S7
and
Figure
4
c, respectively). At faster plating and stripping, the superiority of the PVDF#Cu was more emphasized when the potential profiles were compared between PVDF#Cu and Cu (
Figure
4
d). The PVDF#Cu exhibited no potential overshoots over all cycles. However, the overshoots indicating kinetically slow nucleation and initial stripping were observed for the bare cooper at earlier cycles such as the 10th and 50th. On the other hand, the diffusion overpotentials of plateaus were identical at the 10th cycle. However, the diffusion overpotential of Cu increased seriously with cycles, while it did not change significantly in PVDF#Cu. At the 150th cycle, the potential profiles of the bare copper were noisy, which indicated a short circuit caused by a serious dendritic growth. The insignificant overshoot of PVDF#Cu was interpreted as the proof that more number of nucleation sites or initial stripping sites was developed. The less diffusion overpotential was understood to be due to faster lithium ion transport. The Li
+
affinity sites distributed along ferroelectrically polarized beta-PVDF fibers
(28)
and the faster lithium ion transport by hopping between the negatively biased fluorine sites of beta-PVDF
(28)
are presumed to be responsible for nucleation (or initial stripping) and diffusion overpotential reduction, respectively.

A full cell was constructed by using the lithium metal-loaded PVDF#Cu as an anode and LiFePO
4
(LFP) as a cathode (
[email protected]
#Cu∥LFP). The loading density of LFP on the cathode was 2.3 mAh cm
–2
, while 2 mAh cm
–2
lithium metal was deposited on the anode. For comparison, a copper foil current collector on which the same amount of lithium metal was pre-electrodeposited was used as an anode of the nonferroelectric control cell (
[email protected]
∥LFP). Both cells showed the almost identical potential profile at the first charging and discharging at a slow rate, 0.1C (0.1C = 0.23 mA cm
–2
;
Figure
5
a). The use of the beta-PVDF web improved kinetics and exhibited better rate capability when compared with the bare copper electrode (
Figure
5
b). The
[email protected]
∥LFP cell did not work at 5C, but the
[email protected]
#Cu∥LFP delivered 40% of the capacity at 0.1C (63 mAh g
–1
) at the same rate. The decrease in charge transfer resistance in the presence of beta-PVDF (from 53 ohm to 30 ohm) supported the improved rate capability (
Figure S8
). This impedance spectroscopic result was explained by the metallicity induced by the ferroelectricity of beta-PVDF in a previous report.
(35)

div.p:
Figure 5. Lithium metal battery cells constructed from a lithium metal-loaded anode and LFP cathode. Loading density of LFP on a cathode, 2.3 mAh cm
–2
; loading density of lithium metal on PVDF#Cu or Cu, 2 mAh cm
–2
; electrolyte, 1 M LiPF
6
in EC/DMC (3/7, v/v) with 3 wt % FEC. (a) Cell voltage profile of charging and discharging at 0.1C. The voltage was cut off at 3.8 V for charging and 2.0 V for discharging. (b) Cell capacity at various C rates. (c) Capacity retention along cycles at 1C/1C.

div.div:
As expected,
[email protected]
#Cu∥LFP was much superior to
[email protected]
∥LFP in terms of lithium metal plating/stripping reversibility along cycles (
Figure
5
c). We compared the cyclability between the PVDF-present cell and the PVDF-absent cell at 1C or 2.3 mA cm
–2
. It should be emphasized that this current density value is high enough to demonstrate that the PVDF web architecture is beneficial especially at a high current. The superiority of the PVDF#Cu to the bare copper foil was simply represented by the cycle retention at the 400th cycle: 82.8% for PVDF#Cu versus 16.2% for Cu. This reversibility at a high rate was regarded to be excellent when compared with previously reported works (
Figure S2
), as mentioned earlier.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this work, we presented a nano-web of ferroelectric beta-phase PVDF fibers loaded on copper foil (PVDF#Cu) as a three-dimensional scaffold platform for lithium plating and stripping. This nano-web scaffold architecture was designed to utilize the ferroelectric benefit of a thin solid film of beta-PVDF in a previously reported work
(28)
and, moreover, overcome the kinetic limit of the thin-film architecture. The architecture ensured facile lithium ion transport (1) through electrolyte channels between beta-PVDF fibers and (2) along the ferroelectric surface via lithium ion hopping on the fluoride side of the PVDF. Also, the volume change of lithium metal during plating and stripping was accommodated in the three-dimensional scaffold. The ferroelectric effect of beta-PVDF was confirmed by the dense and continuous growth of lithium metal within the web architecture of the PVDF#Cu. The kinetic benefit expected from the ferroelectric lithium ion transport of beta-PVDF as well as the porous architecture of PVDF#Cu (porosity > 0.9) was realized in a cell of LFP as a cathode and lithium-plated PVDF#Cu as an anode with a practically used carbonate electrolyte. Excellent plating/stripping reversibility along repeated cycles even at a high current such as 2.3 mA cm
–2
was successfully demonstrated in the cell, which was not obtained by nonferroelectric polymer materials (PAN#Cu in this work).

A Review of Solid Electrolyte Interphases on Lithium Metal Anode
Cheng Xin-Bing; Zhang Rui; Zhao Chen-Zi; Wei Fei; Zhang Qiang; Zhang Ji-Guang
Advanced science (Weinheim, Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany)
(
2016
),
3
(
3
),
1500213
ISSN:
2198-3844
.
Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) are among the most promising candidates of high-energy-density devices for advanced energy storage. However, the growth of dendrites greatly hinders the practical applications of LMBs in portable electronics and electric vehicles. Constructing stable and efficient solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is among the most effective strategies to inhibit the dendrite growth and thus to achieve a superior cycling performance. In this review, the mechanisms of SEI formation and models of SEI structure are briefly summarized. The analysis methods to probe the surface chemistry, surface morphology, electrochemical property, dynamic characteristics of SEI layer are emphasized. The critical factors affecting the SEI formation, such as electrolyte component, temperature, current density, are comprehensively debated. The efficient methods to modify SEI layer with the introduction of new electrolyte system and additives, ex-situ-formed protective layer, as well as electrode design, are summarized. Although these works afford new insights into SEI research, robust and precise routes for SEI modification with well-designed structure, as well as understanding of the connection between structure and electrochemical performance, is still inadequate. A multidisciplinary approach is highly required to enable the formation of robust SEI for highly efficient energy storage systems.

A review is given. Li-ion batteries have had a profound impact on our daily life, but inherent limitations make it difficult for Li-ion chemistries to meet the growing demands for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Therefore, chemistries beyond Li-ion are currently being investigated and need to be made viable for com. applications. The use of metallic Li is one of the most favored choices for next-generation Li batteries, esp. Li-S and Li-air systems. After falling into oblivion for several decades because of safety concerns, metallic Li is now ready for a revival, thanks to the development of investigative tools and nanotechnol.-based solns. Here, we 1st summarize the current understanding on Li anodes, then highlight the recent key progress in materials design and advanced characterization techniques, and finally discuss the opportunities and possible directions for future development of Li anodes in applications.

Making Li-metal electrodes rechargeable by controlling the dendrite growth direction
Liu, Yadong; Liu, Qi; Xin, Le; Liu, Yuzi; Yang, Fan; Stach, Eric A.; Xie, Jian

The long-standing issue of Li-dendrite formation and growth during repeated plating or stripping processes prevents the practical application of Li-metal anodes for high-specific-energy batteries. Here we develop an approach to control dendrite growth by coating the separator with functionalized nanocarbon (FNC) with immobilized Li ions. During cycling, the Li dendrites grow toward each other simultaneously from both the FNC layer on the separator and the Li-metal anode; when the dendrites meet, the growth changes direction: rather than penetrating the separator, a dense Li layer is formed between the separator and the Li anode. This controlled growth alleviates the solid electrolyte interphase formation, reduces the decompn. of the electrolyte, and improves the cyclability of the Li-metal cell. In a Li/LiFePO4 coin cell with three different electrolytes, we show that this approach enables a long stable cycle life (>800 cycles with 80% retention of the initial capacity) and improved efficiency (>97%). Our method offers promise for application in practical Li-metal batteries, and it may also be useful for tackling dendrite issues for other metals.

Liu, Yayuan; Lin, Dingchang; Liang, Zheng; Zhao, Jie; Yan, Kai; Cui, Yi

Lithium metal is the ideal anode for the next generation of high-energy-d. batteries. Nevertheless, dendrite growth, side reactions and infinite relative vol. change have prevented it from practical applications. Here, we demonstrate a promising metallic lithium anode design by infusing molten lithium into a polymeric matrix. The electrospun polyimide employed is stable against highly reactive molten lithium and, via a conformal layer of zinc oxide coating to render the surface lithiophilic, molten lithium can be drawn into the matrix, affording a nano-porous lithium electrode. Importantly, the polymeric backbone enables uniform lithium stripping/plating, which successfully confines lithium within the matrix, realizing min. vol. change and effective dendrite suppression. The porous electrode reduces the effective c.d.; thus, flat voltage profiles and stable cycling of more than 100 cycles is achieved even at a high c.d. of 5 mA cm-2 in both carbonate and ether electrolyte. The advantages of the porous, polymeric matrix provide important insights into the design principles of lithium metal anodes.

Lithium metal is considered to be one of the most potential anode materials on account of its high theor. specific capacity and lowermost electrochem. potential. Nevertheless, the crit. challenges of dendrite growth and low Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the lithium metal anode during cycling prevent the com. application of the lithium metal battery. Herein, rubidium fluoride (RbF) as additives is used to inhibit the lithium dendrite growth. Benefiting from the stronger electropos. property of Rb+, it can adsorb on the surface of protuberances during the lithium deposition process, form an electrostatic shielding field of the surface, and guide the uniform deposition of Li+. The CE can maintain >90% with the additives of RbF in the carbonate electrolyte. Besides that, RbF improves the cycle life and decreases the polarization, a stable cycling performance of >1000 h is obtained, and the overvoltage is controlled <100 mV in the cycling test of Li‖Li sym. cells at 0.5 mA/cm2. The addn. of RbF offers a feasible way for the development of lithium metal batteries (LMBs) in the future.

The formation of lithium dendrites induces the notorious safety issue and poor cycling life of energy storage devices, such as lithium-sulfur and lithium-air batteries. We propose a surface energy model to describe the complex interface between the lithium anode and electrolyte. A universal strategy of hindering formation of lithium dendrites via tuning surface energy of the relevant thin film growth is suggested. The merit of the novel motif lies not only fundamentally a perfect correlation between electrochemistry and thin film fields, but also significantly promotes larger-scale application of lithium-sulfur and lithium-air batteries, as well as other metal batteries (e.g., Zn, Na, K, Cu, Ag, and Sn).

A review is presented. The lithium metal battery is strongly considered to be one of the most promising candidates for high-energy-d. energy storage devices in our modern and technol.-based society. However, uncontrollable lithium dendrite growth induces poor cycling efficiency and severe safety concerns, dragging lithium metal batteries out of practical applications. This review presents a comprehensive overview of the lithium metal anode and its dendritic lithium growth. First, the working principles and tech. challenges of a lithium metal anode are underscored. Specific attention is paid to the mechanistic understandings and quant. models for solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation, lithium dendrite nucleation, and growth. On the basis of previous theor. understanding and anal., recently proposed strategies to suppress dendrite growth of lithium metal anode and some other metal anodes are reviewed. A section dedicated to the potential of full-cell lithium metal batteries for practical applications is included. A general conclusion and a perspective on the current limitations and recommended future research directions of lithium metal batteries are presented. The review concludes with an attempt at summarizing the theor. and exptl. achievements in lithium metal anodes and endeavors to realize the practical applications of lithium metal batteries.

The effect of mech. surface modification on the performance of lithium metal foil electrodes is systematically investigated. The applied micro-needle surface treatment technique for Li metal has various advantages. First, this economical and efficient technique is able to cover a wide range of surface area with a simple rolling process, which can be easily carried out. Second, this technique achieves improved rate capability and cycling stability, as well as a reduced interfacial resistance. The micro-needle treatment improves the rate capability by 20% (0.750 mA-h at a rate of 7C) and increases the cycling stability by 200% (85% of the initial discharge capacity after 150 cycles) compared to untreated bare Li metal (0.626 mA-h at a rate of 7C, 85% of the initial discharge capacity after only 70 cycles). Third, this technique efficiently suppresses Li formation of high surface area Li during the Li deposition process, as preferred sites for controlled Li plating are generated.

Stabilization of Lithium Metal Anodes by Hybrid Artificial Solid Electrolyte Interphase
Kozen, Alexander C.; Lin, Chuan-Fu; Zhao, Oliver; Lee, Sang Bok; Rubloff, Gary W.; Noked, Malachi

Li metal is among the most attractive anode materials for secondary batteries, with a theor. specific capacity > 3800 mAh g-1. However, its extremely low electrochem. potential is assocd. with high chem. reactivity that results in undesirable redn. of electrolyte species on the lithium surface, leading to spontaneous formation of a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) with uncontrolled compn., morphol., and physicochem. properties. Here, we demonstrate a new approach to stabilize Li metal anodes using a hybrid org./inorg. artificial solid electrolyte interphase (ASEI) deposited directly on the Li metal surface by self-healing electrochem. polymn. (EP) and at. layer deposition (ALD). This hybrid protection layer is thin, flexible, ionically conductive, and elec. insulating. We show that Li metal protected by the hybrid protection layer gives rise to very stable cycling performance for over 300 cycles at c.d. 1 mA/cm2 and over 110 cycles at c.d. 2 mA/cm2, well above the threshold for dendrite growth at unprotected Li. Our strategy for protecting Li metal anodes by hybrid org./inorg. ASEI represents a new approach to mitigating or eliminating dendrite formation at reactive metal anodes-illustrated here for Li-and may expedite the realization of a "beyond-Li-ion" battery technol. employing Li metal anodes (e.g., Li-S).

The enhanced stability of lithium metal is vital to the development of high energy d. lithium batteries due to its higher specific capacity and low redox potential. Herein, it is demonstrated that nitrogen and sulfur codoped graphene (NSG) nanosheets coated on a polyethylene separator stabilized the lithium electrode in lithium metal batteries by effectively suppressing dendrite growth and maintaining a uniform ionic flux on the metal surface. The ultrathin layer of NSG nanosheets also improved the dimensional stability of the polymer separator at elevated temps. In addn., the enhanced interfacial interaction between the NSG-coated separator and lithium metal via electrostatic attraction released the surface tension of lithium metal and suppressed the initiation of dendrite growth on lithium metal. As a result, the electrochem. performance of a lithium metal cell composed of a LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 pos. electrode with an NSG-coated separator was remarkably improved as compared to the cell with an uncoated polyethylene separator.

The property of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer is of prime importance for the performance of lithium metal anodes. Replacing the spontaneously formed inhomogeneous and unstable SEI layer with a high-performance artificial SEI is an effective strategy. Herein, a self-healing SEI layer with high lithium-ion cond. and a stable framework to address the issues of poor performance of lithium metal anodes is achieved. C, Li2S, and LiI are uniformly distributed on the lithium surface via a "sauna" reaction between CS2-I2 mixed steam and metal lithium, which has the potential to be applied to large-scale prepn. The obtained SEI layer possesses high mech. strength and facilitated lithium-ion transport capability, which are inherited from the amorphous C and lithium compds. (Li2S and LiI). Most importantly, the LiI component can migrate through the electrolyte and cover the exposed lithium caused by flaws and cracks, leading to a self-healing property. As a result, the
[email protected]
electrode exhibits excellent electrochem. performance with low overpotential and long lifespan.

Due to the volatility of P2S5, the ambient pressure synthesis of Li2S + P2S5 (LPS) has been limited to planetary ball-milling (PBM). To utilize PBM of LPS to generate a solid electrolyte (SE), the as-synthesized powder sample must be pressed into pellets, and as such the presence of as-pressed grain boundaries in the SE cannot be avoided. To eliminate the grain boundaries, LPS doped with SiS2 has been studied because SiS2 lowers the vapor pressure of the melt and promotes strong glass formation, which in combination allows for greater ease in synthesis. In this work, the structures and electrochem. properties are examd. of lithium thiosilicophosphate 0.6Li2S + 0.4[xSiS2 + 1.5(1 - x)PS5/2], 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, glassy solid electrolytes (GSEs) prepd. by both PBM and melt-quenching (MQ). It is shown that the crit. c.d. improved after incorporating SiS2, reaching 1.5 mA/cm2 for the x = 0.8 compn. However, the interfacial reaction of MQ GSE with lithium metal introduced microcracks, which shows that further research is needed to explore and develop more stable GSE compns. These fundamental results can help to understand the interface reaction and formation and as such can provide a guide to design improved homogeneous GSEs with SiS2 as a glass former, which have no grain boundaries and thereby may help suppress lithium dendrite formation.

Metallic Li, with its high capacity and low redox potential, shows significant development potential for high-energy-d. Li batteries. Unfortunately, huge volumetric changes, uncontrollable Li dendrites, and interfacial parasitic reactions limit its com. application. Here, we demonstrate a rational strategy of encapsulating metallic Li into the interior spaces of hollow C nanocages for dendrite-free Li metal anodes. We find that the poly(vinylidene difluoride)-binder-modified thin-layer C walls on the C nanocages can guide Li deposition into the interior spaces of these hollow C nanocages and simultaneously reduce the interfacial parasitic reactions between deposited Li metal and an electrolyte. Because of the high sp. surface area and huge interior spaces of the C nanocages, the local c.d. can be reduced and large vol. changes are mitigated. Specifically, this electrode exhibits negligible vol. changes at 1.0 mAh/cm2 and a 14.9% vol. change at 3.0 mAh/cm2. The Cu foil electrode exhibits 87.9 and 234.3% vol. changes at the corresponding deposition capacities. Consequently, a C-nanocage-modified electrode exhibits an outstanding Coulombic efficiency of 99.7% for ∼150 cycles at a c.d. of 1.0 mA/cm2, while a Cu foil electrode exhibits <70.0% Coulombic efficiency after only 43 cycles. When paired with a S cathode, the C-nanocage-modified electrode exhibits better cycling and rate performances than the pristine Cu foil electrode.

Li metal is the most promising electrode for next-generation rechargeable batteries. However, the challenges induced by Li dendrites on a working Li metal anode hinder the practical applications of Li metal batteries. Here, N-doped graphene was adopted as the Li plating matrix to regulate Li metal nucleation and suppress dendrite growth. The N-contg. functional groups, such as pyridinic and pyrrolic N in the N-doped graphene, are lithiophilic, which guide the metallic Li nucleation causing the metal to distribute uniformly on the anode surface. The N-doped graphene modified Li metal anode exhibits a dendrite-free morphol. during repeated Li plating and demonstrates a high Coulombic efficiency of 98% for ∼200 cycles.

Zhang Huimin; Xiang Yu; Li Meng; Zhang Wenfeng; Zhu Xiayu; Ming Hai; Lu Lin; Qiu Jingyi; Cao Gaoping; Yang Yusheng; Zhang Hao; Zhang Huimin; Liao Xiaobin; Mai Liqiang; Liao Xiaobin; Zhao Yan; Guan Yuepeng; Huang Yaqin

The long-standing issue of lithium dendrite growth during repeated deposition or dissolution processes hinders the practical use of lithium-metal anodes for high-energy density batteries. Here, we demonstrate a promising lithiophilic-lithiophobic gradient interfacial layer strategy in which the bottom lithiophilic zinc oxide/carbon nanotube sublayer tightly anchors the whole layer onto the lithium foil, facilitating the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase, and prevents the formation of an intermediate mossy lithium corrosion layer. Together with the top lithiophobic carbon nanotube sublayer, this gradient interfacial layer can effectively suppress dendrite growth and ensure ultralong-term stable lithium stripping/plating. This strategy is further demonstrated to provide substantially improved cycle performance in copper current collector, 10 cm(2) pouch cell and lithium-sulfur batteries, which, coupled with a simple fabrication process and wide applicability in various materials for lithium-metal protection, makes the lithiophilic-lithiophobic gradient interfacial layer a favored strategy for next-generation lithium-metal batteries.

We report the use of vinyl ethylene carbonate as a new solid electrolyte interface (SEI)-forming additive for Li-metal anodes in carbonate-based electrolyte, which has the advantages of both good storage performance and low price. Compared to the SEI formed in vinyl ethylene carbonate-free electrolyte, the SEI film formed in 10% vinyl ethylene carbonate electrolyte contains a higher relative content of polycarbonate species and a greater amt. of decompn. products of LiPF6 salt. Both components are expected to have pos. effects on the passivation of Li-metal surface and the accommodation of vol. changes of anode during cycling. When cycling at the c.d. of 0.25 mA cm-2 with a cycling capacity of 1.0 mAh cm-2, the vinyl ethylene carbonate-contained Li-Cu cell exhibits a long life span of 816 h (100 cycles) and a relatively high Coulombic efficiency of 93.2%.

The effects of lithium imide and lithium orthoborate dual-salt electrolytes of different salt chemistries in carbonate solvents on the cycling stability of lithium (Li) metal batteries are systematically and comparatively investigated. Two imide salts (LiTFSI and LiFSI) and two orthoborate salts (LiBOB and LiDFOB) are chosen for this study and compared with the conventional LiPF6 salt. D. functional theory calcns. indicate that the chem. and electrochem. stabilities rank in the following order: LiTFSI-LiBOB > LiTFSI-LiDFOB > LiFSI-LiDFOB > LiFSI-LiBOB. The exptl. cycling stability of the Li metal batteries with the electrolytes ranks in the following order: LiTFSI-LiBOB > LiTFSI-LiDFOB > LiFSI-LiDFOB > LiPF6 > LiFSI-LiBOB, which is in well accordance with the calcn. results. The LiTFSI-LiBOB can effectively protect the Al substrate and form a more robust surface film on Li metal anode, while the LiFSI-LiBOB results in serious corrosion to the stainless steel cell case and a thicker and looser surface film on Li anode. The key findings of this work emphasize that the salt chem. is critically important for enhancing the interfacial stability of Li metal anode and should be carefully manipulated in the development of high-performance Li metal batteries.

Effective transformation from paraelec. to a high fraction of ferroelec. phase is crucial to produce piezoelec. materials with a high piezoelec. const. for broad applications. In polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) thin films, both mech. stretching and elec. poling processes have been found to be crit. in the α β phase transformation. However, in PVDF fibers fabricated by the electrospinning process, the roles of mech. stretching and elec. poling have not been well explored. Here, the properties of PVDF fibers from electrospinning and forcespinning, a mech. spinning process without elec. poling, have been characterized and analyzed by FTIR and XRD spectroscopic techniques. The results show that pure mech. stretching in the forcespun fibers can result in a high fraction of the all-trans β-phase, at 95%. Electrospun fibers from the same material system, on the other hand, can also reach a high fraction of β-phase, at approx. 99%. These results preliminarily demonstrate that mech. stretching is the main reason for β-phase induction in PVDF fibers. Further expts. performed in this work show that higher wt% of PVDF, lower polymer soln. supply rate, and more uniformly mixed solvent systems facilitate achieving a higher level of ferroelec. β-phase in electrospun PVDF fibers.

We have shown that β-phase PVDF fibers can be electrospun directly from a DMF (DMF) soln. with a max. fraction of β phase, F(β)max, of 0.75. The fraction of β phase is found to be greater for smaller-diam. fibers and those spun at an increased voltage.

The ion-conduction properties of a PEO-based composite polymer electrolyte comprised of PEO, LiClO4, and the ferroelec. material BaTiO3 were studied. The addn. of BaTiO3 resulted in an increase in cond. over the temp. range 25-1150. The optimum amt. of BaTiO3 (purity 99.9%, particle size 0.6-1.2 μm) was 1.4 wt% which is very low in comparison with previously reported composite polymer electrolytes. The ionic cond. of a composite polymer electrolyte contg. 1.4 wt% BaTiO3 was 1 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 25°, which is at least one order of magnitude higher than that of the pristine polymer electrolyte (4 × 10-7 S cm-1). The transport no. of the lithium ion in this composite polymer electrolyte was higher than that of the pristine polymer electrolyte. The increase in the cond. and the lithium-ion transport no. is explained on the basis of the spontaneous polarization of the ferroelec. material due to its particular crystal structure. The addn. of BaTiO3 powder greatly enhanced the lithium/electrolyte interface stability.

Lithium metal is one of the most promising candidates as an anode material for next-generation energy storage systems due to its highest specific capacity (3860 mAh/g) and lowest redox potential of all. The uncontrolled lithium dendrite growth that causes a poor cycling performance and serious safety hazards, however, presents a significant challenge for the realization of lithium metal-based batteries. Here, we demonstrate a novel electrode design by placing a three-dimensional (3D) oxidized polyacrylonitrile nanofiber network on top of the current collector. The polymer fiber with polar surface functional groups could guide the lithium ions to form uniform lithium metal deposits confined on the polymer fiber surface and in the 3D polymer layer. We showed stable cycling of lithium metal anode with an av. Coulombic efficiency of 97.4% over 120 cycles in ether-based electrolyte at a c.d. of 3 mA/cm2 for a total of 1 mAh/cm2 of lithium.

A Review of Solid Electrolyte Interphases on Lithium Metal Anode
Cheng Xin-Bing; Zhang Rui; Zhao Chen-Zi; Wei Fei; Zhang Qiang; Zhang Ji-Guang
Advanced science (Weinheim, Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany)
(
2016
),
3
(
3
),
1500213
ISSN:
2198-3844
.
Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) are among the most promising candidates of high-energy-density devices for advanced energy storage. However, the growth of dendrites greatly hinders the practical applications of LMBs in portable electronics and electric vehicles. Constructing stable and efficient solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is among the most effective strategies to inhibit the dendrite growth and thus to achieve a superior cycling performance. In this review, the mechanisms of SEI formation and models of SEI structure are briefly summarized. The analysis methods to probe the surface chemistry, surface morphology, electrochemical property, dynamic characteristics of SEI layer are emphasized. The critical factors affecting the SEI formation, such as electrolyte component, temperature, current density, are comprehensively debated. The efficient methods to modify SEI layer with the introduction of new electrolyte system and additives, ex-situ-formed protective layer, as well as electrode design, are summarized. Although these works afford new insights into SEI research, robust and precise routes for SEI modification with well-designed structure, as well as understanding of the connection between structure and electrochemical performance, is still inadequate. A multidisciplinary approach is highly required to enable the formation of robust SEI for highly efficient energy storage systems.

A review is given. Li-ion batteries have had a profound impact on our daily life, but inherent limitations make it difficult for Li-ion chemistries to meet the growing demands for portable electronics, elec. vehicles and grid-scale energy storage. Therefore, chemistries beyond Li-ion are currently being investigated and need to be made viable for com. applications. The use of metallic Li is one of the most favored choices for next-generation Li batteries, esp. Li-S and Li-air systems. After falling into oblivion for several decades because of safety concerns, metallic Li is now ready for a revival, thanks to the development of investigative tools and nanotechnol.-based solns. Here, we 1st summarize the current understanding on Li anodes, then highlight the recent key progress in materials design and advanced characterization techniques, and finally discuss the opportunities and possible directions for future development of Li anodes in applications.

Making Li-metal electrodes rechargeable by controlling the dendrite growth direction
Liu, Yadong; Liu, Qi; Xin, Le; Liu, Yuzi; Yang, Fan; Stach, Eric A.; Xie, Jian

The long-standing issue of Li-dendrite formation and growth during repeated plating or stripping processes prevents the practical application of Li-metal anodes for high-specific-energy batteries. Here we develop an approach to control dendrite growth by coating the separator with functionalized nanocarbon (FNC) with immobilized Li ions. During cycling, the Li dendrites grow toward each other simultaneously from both the FNC layer on the separator and the Li-metal anode; when the dendrites meet, the growth changes direction: rather than penetrating the separator, a dense Li layer is formed between the separator and the Li anode. This controlled growth alleviates the solid electrolyte interphase formation, reduces the decompn. of the electrolyte, and improves the cyclability of the Li-metal cell. In a Li/LiFePO4 coin cell with three different electrolytes, we show that this approach enables a long stable cycle life (>800 cycles with 80% retention of the initial capacity) and improved efficiency (>97%). Our method offers promise for application in practical Li-metal batteries, and it may also be useful for tackling dendrite issues for other metals.

Lithium metal is the ideal anode for the next generation of high-energy-d. batteries. Nevertheless, dendrite growth, side reactions and infinite relative vol. change have prevented it from practical applications. Here, we demonstrate a promising metallic lithium anode design by infusing molten lithium into a polymeric matrix. The electrospun polyimide employed is stable against highly reactive molten lithium and, via a conformal layer of zinc oxide coating to render the surface lithiophilic, molten lithium can be drawn into the matrix, affording a nano-porous lithium electrode. Importantly, the polymeric backbone enables uniform lithium stripping/plating, which successfully confines lithium within the matrix, realizing min. vol. change and effective dendrite suppression. The porous electrode reduces the effective c.d.; thus, flat voltage profiles and stable cycling of more than 100 cycles is achieved even at a high c.d. of 5 mA cm-2 in both carbonate and ether electrolyte. The advantages of the porous, polymeric matrix provide important insights into the design principles of lithium metal anodes.

Lithium metal is considered to be one of the most potential anode materials on account of its high theor. specific capacity and lowermost electrochem. potential. Nevertheless, the crit. challenges of dendrite growth and low Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the lithium metal anode during cycling prevent the com. application of the lithium metal battery. Herein, rubidium fluoride (RbF) as additives is used to inhibit the lithium dendrite growth. Benefiting from the stronger electropos. property of Rb+, it can adsorb on the surface of protuberances during the lithium deposition process, form an electrostatic shielding field of the surface, and guide the uniform deposition of Li+. The CE can maintain >90% with the additives of RbF in the carbonate electrolyte. Besides that, RbF improves the cycle life and decreases the polarization, a stable cycling performance of >1000 h is obtained, and the overvoltage is controlled <100 mV in the cycling test of Li‖Li sym. cells at 0.5 mA/cm2. The addn. of RbF offers a feasible way for the development of lithium metal batteries (LMBs) in the future.

The formation of lithium dendrites induces the notorious safety issue and poor cycling life of energy storage devices, such as lithium-sulfur and lithium-air batteries. We propose a surface energy model to describe the complex interface between the lithium anode and electrolyte. A universal strategy of hindering formation of lithium dendrites via tuning surface energy of the relevant thin film growth is suggested. The merit of the novel motif lies not only fundamentally a perfect correlation between electrochemistry and thin film fields, but also significantly promotes larger-scale application of lithium-sulfur and lithium-air batteries, as well as other metal batteries (e.g., Zn, Na, K, Cu, Ag, and Sn).

A review is presented. The lithium metal battery is strongly considered to be one of the most promising candidates for high-energy-d. energy storage devices in our modern and technol.-based society. However, uncontrollable lithium dendrite growth induces poor cycling efficiency and severe safety concerns, dragging lithium metal batteries out of practical applications. This review presents a comprehensive overview of the lithium metal anode and its dendritic lithium growth. First, the working principles and tech. challenges of a lithium metal anode are underscored. Specific attention is paid to the mechanistic understandings and quant. models for solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation, lithium dendrite nucleation, and growth. On the basis of previous theor. understanding and anal., recently proposed strategies to suppress dendrite growth of lithium metal anode and some other metal anodes are reviewed. A section dedicated to the potential of full-cell lithium metal batteries for practical applications is included. A general conclusion and a perspective on the current limitations and recommended future research directions of lithium metal batteries are presented. The review concludes with an attempt at summarizing the theor. and exptl. achievements in lithium metal anodes and endeavors to realize the practical applications of lithium metal batteries.

The effect of mech. surface modification on the performance of lithium metal foil electrodes is systematically investigated. The applied micro-needle surface treatment technique for Li metal has various advantages. First, this economical and efficient technique is able to cover a wide range of surface area with a simple rolling process, which can be easily carried out. Second, this technique achieves improved rate capability and cycling stability, as well as a reduced interfacial resistance. The micro-needle treatment improves the rate capability by 20% (0.750 mA-h at a rate of 7C) and increases the cycling stability by 200% (85% of the initial discharge capacity after 150 cycles) compared to untreated bare Li metal (0.626 mA-h at a rate of 7C, 85% of the initial discharge capacity after only 70 cycles). Third, this technique efficiently suppresses Li formation of high surface area Li during the Li deposition process, as preferred sites for controlled Li plating are generated.

Li metal is among the most attractive anode materials for secondary batteries, with a theor. specific capacity > 3800 mAh g-1. However, its extremely low electrochem. potential is assocd. with high chem. reactivity that results in undesirable redn. of electrolyte species on the lithium surface, leading to spontaneous formation of a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) with uncontrolled compn., morphol., and physicochem. properties. Here, we demonstrate a new approach to stabilize Li metal anodes using a hybrid org./inorg. artificial solid electrolyte interphase (ASEI) deposited directly on the Li metal surface by self-healing electrochem. polymn. (EP) and at. layer deposition (ALD). This hybrid protection layer is thin, flexible, ionically conductive, and elec. insulating. We show that Li metal protected by the hybrid protection layer gives rise to very stable cycling performance for over 300 cycles at c.d. 1 mA/cm2 and over 110 cycles at c.d. 2 mA/cm2, well above the threshold for dendrite growth at unprotected Li. Our strategy for protecting Li metal anodes by hybrid org./inorg. ASEI represents a new approach to mitigating or eliminating dendrite formation at reactive metal anodes-illustrated here for Li-and may expedite the realization of a "beyond-Li-ion" battery technol. employing Li metal anodes (e.g., Li-S).

The enhanced stability of lithium metal is vital to the development of high energy d. lithium batteries due to its higher specific capacity and low redox potential. Herein, it is demonstrated that nitrogen and sulfur codoped graphene (NSG) nanosheets coated on a polyethylene separator stabilized the lithium electrode in lithium metal batteries by effectively suppressing dendrite growth and maintaining a uniform ionic flux on the metal surface. The ultrathin layer of NSG nanosheets also improved the dimensional stability of the polymer separator at elevated temps. In addn., the enhanced interfacial interaction between the NSG-coated separator and lithium metal via electrostatic attraction released the surface tension of lithium metal and suppressed the initiation of dendrite growth on lithium metal. As a result, the electrochem. performance of a lithium metal cell composed of a LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 pos. electrode with an NSG-coated separator was remarkably improved as compared to the cell with an uncoated polyethylene separator.

Replacing the spontaneously formed inhomogeneous and unstable SEI layer with a high-performance artificial SEI is an effective strategy. Herein, a self-healing SEI layer with high lithium-ion cond. and a stable framework to address the issues of poor performance of lithium metal anodes is achieved. C, Li2S, and LiI are uniformly distributed on the lithium surface via a "sauna" reaction between CS2-I2 mixed steam and metal lithium, which has the potential to be applied to large-scale prepn. The obtained SEI layer possesses high mech. strength and facilitated lithium-ion transport capability, which are inherited from the amorphous C and lithium compds. (Li2S and LiI). Most importantly, the LiI component can migrate through the electrolyte and cover the exposed lithium caused by flaws and cracks, leading to a self-healing property. As a result, the

Due to the volatility of P2S5, the ambient pressure synthesis of Li2S + P2S5 (LPS) has been limited to planetary ball-milling (PBM). To utilize PBM of LPS to generate a solid electrolyte (SE), the as-synthesized powder sample must be pressed into pellets, and as such the presence of as-pressed grain boundaries in the SE cannot be avoided. To eliminate the grain boundaries, LPS doped with SiS2 has been studied because SiS2 lowers the vapor pressure of the melt and promotes strong glass formation, which in combination allows for greater ease in synthesis. In this work, the structures and electrochem. properties are examd. of lithium thiosilicophosphate 0.6Li2S + 0.4[xSiS2 + 1.5(1 - x)PS5/2], 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, glassy solid electrolytes (GSEs) prepd. by both PBM and melt-quenching (MQ). It is shown that the crit. c.d. improved after incorporating SiS2, reaching 1.5 mA/cm2 for the x = 0.8 compn. However, the interfacial reaction of MQ GSE with lithium metal introduced microcracks, which shows that further research is needed to explore and develop more stable GSE compns. These fundamental results can help to understand the interface reaction and formation and as such can provide a guide to design improved homogeneous GSEs with SiS2 as a glass former, which have no grain boundaries and thereby may help suppress lithium dendrite formation.

Metallic Li, with its high capacity and low redox potential, shows significant development potential for high-energy-d. Li batteries. Unfortunately, huge volumetric changes, uncontrollable Li dendrites, and interfacial parasitic reactions limit its com. application. Here, we demonstrate a rational strategy of encapsulating metallic Li into the interior spaces of hollow C nanocages for dendrite-free Li metal anodes. We find that the poly(vinylidene difluoride)-binder-modified thin-layer C walls on the C nanocages can guide Li deposition into the interior spaces of these hollow C nanocages and simultaneously reduce the interfacial parasitic reactions between deposited Li metal and an electrolyte. Because of the high sp. surface area and huge interior spaces of the C nanocages, the local c.d. can be reduced and large vol. changes are mitigated. Specifically, this electrode exhibits negligible vol. changes at 1.0 mAh/cm2 and a 14.9% vol. change at 3.0 mAh/cm2. The Cu foil electrode exhibits 87.9 and 234.3% vol. changes at the corresponding deposition capacities. Consequently, a C-nanocage-modified electrode exhibits an outstanding Coulombic efficiency of 99.7% for ∼150 cycles at a c.d. of 1.0 mA/cm2, while a Cu foil electrode exhibits <70.0% Coulombic efficiency after only 43 cycles. When paired with a S cathode, the C-nanocage-modified electrode exhibits better cycling and rate performances than the pristine Cu foil electrode.

Li metal is the most promising electrode for next-generation rechargeable batteries. However, the challenges induced by Li dendrites on a working Li metal anode hinder the practical applications of Li metal batteries. Here, N-doped graphene was adopted as the Li plating matrix to regulate Li metal nucleation and suppress dendrite growth. The N-contg. functional groups, such as pyridinic and pyrrolic N in the N-doped graphene, are lithiophilic, which guide the metallic Li nucleation causing the metal to distribute uniformly on the anode surface. The N-doped graphene modified Li metal anode exhibits a dendrite-free morphol. during repeated Li plating and demonstrates a high Coulombic efficiency of 98% for ∼200 cycles.

Zhang Huimin; Xiang Yu; Li Meng; Zhang Wenfeng; Zhu Xiayu; Ming Hai; Lu Lin; Qiu Jingyi; Cao Gaoping; Yang Yusheng; Zhang Hao; Zhang Huimin; Liao Xiaobin; Mai Liqiang; Liao Xiaobin; Zhao Yan; Guan Yuepeng; Huang Yaqin

The long-standing issue of lithium dendrite growth during repeated deposition or dissolution processes hinders the practical use of lithium-metal anodes for high-energy density batteries. Here, we demonstrate a promising lithiophilic-lithiophobic gradient interfacial layer strategy in which the bottom lithiophilic zinc oxide/carbon nanotube sublayer tightly anchors the whole layer onto the lithium foil, facilitating the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase, and prevents the formation of an intermediate mossy lithium corrosion layer. Together with the top lithiophobic carbon nanotube sublayer, this gradient interfacial layer can effectively suppress dendrite growth and ensure ultralong-term stable lithium stripping/plating. This strategy is further demonstrated to provide substantially improved cycle performance in copper current collector, 10 cm(2) pouch cell and lithium-sulfur batteries, which, coupled with a simple fabrication process and wide applicability in various materials for lithium-metal protection, makes the lithiophilic-lithiophobic gradient interfacial layer a favored strategy for next-generation lithium-metal batteries.

We report the use of vinyl ethylene carbonate as a new solid electrolyte interface (SEI)-forming additive for Li-metal anodes in carbonate-based electrolyte, which has the advantages of both good storage performance and low price. Compared to the SEI formed in vinyl ethylene carbonate-free electrolyte, the SEI film formed in 10% vinyl ethylene carbonate electrolyte contains a higher relative content of polycarbonate species and a greater amt. of decompn. products of LiPF6 salt. Both components are expected to have pos. effects on the passivation of Li-metal surface and the accommodation of vol. changes of anode during cycling. The effects of lithium imide and lithium orthoborate dual-salt electrolytes of different salt chemistries in carbonate solvents on the cycling stability of lithium (Li) metal batteries are systematically and comparatively investigated. Two imide salts (LiTFSI and LiFSI) and two orthoborate salts (LiBOB and LiDFOB) are chosen for this study and compared with the conventional LiPF6 salt. D. functional theory calcns. indicate that the chem. and electrochem. stabilities rank in the following order: LiTFSI-LiBOB > LiTFSI-LiDFOB > LiFSI-LiDFOB > LiFSI-LiBOB. The exptl. cycling stability of the Li metal batteries with the electrolytes ranks in the following order: LiTFSI-LiBOB > LiTFSI-LiDFOB > LiFSI-LiDFOB > LiPF6 > LiFSI-LiBOB, which is in well accordance with the calcn. results. The LiTFSI-LiBOB can effectively protect the Al substrate and form a more robust surface film on Li metal anode, while the LiFSI-LiBOB results in serious corrosion to the stainless steel cell case and a thicker and looser surface film on Li anode. The key findings of this work emphasize that the salt chem. is critically important for enhancing the interfacial stability of Li metal anode and should be carefully manipulated in the development of high-performance Li metal batteries.

An interesting and effective route for improving battery performance using ferroelec. poly(vinylidene difluoride) (PVDF) polymer as a binder material is demonstrated in this work. A ferroelec. )
Effective transformation from paraelec. to a high fraction of ferroelec. phase is crucial to produce piezoelec. materials with a high piezoelec. const. for broad applications. In polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) thin films, both mech. stretching and elec. poling processes have been found to be crit. in the α β phase transformation. However, in PVDF fibers fabricated by the electrospinning process, the roles of mech. stretching and elec. poling have not been well explored. Here, the properties of PVDF fibers from electrospinning and forcespinning, a mech. spinning process without elec. poling, have been characterized and analyzed by FTIR and XRD spectroscopic techniques. The results show that pure mech. stretching in the forcespun fibers can result in a high fraction of the all-trans β-phase, at 95%. Electrospun fibers from the same material system, on the other hand, can also reach a high fraction of β-phase, at approx. 99%. These results preliminarily demonstrate that mech. stretching is the main reason for β-phase induction in PVDF fibers. Further expts. performed in this work show that higher wt% of PVDF, lower polymer soln. supply rate, and more uniformly mixed solvent systems facilitate achieving a higher level of ferroelec. β-phase in electrospun PVDF fibers.

Poly(vinylidene difluoride) (PVDF) fibers were prepd. by electrospinning from DMF (DMF) solns. The effects of the electrospinning processing conditions on the formation of the α and β phases of PVDF were studied using IR spectroscopy and differential scanning calorimetry. We have shown that β-phase PVDF fibers can be electrospun directly from a DMF (DMF) soln. with a max. fraction of β phase, F(β)max, of 0.75. The fraction of β phase is found to be greater for smaller-diam. fibers and those spun at an increased voltage.

The ion-conduction properties of a PEO-based composite polymer electrolyte comprised of PEO, LiClO4, and the ferroelec. material BaTiO3 were studied. The addn. of BaTiO3 resulted in an increase in cond. over the temp. range 25-1150. The optimum amt. of BaTiO3 (purity 99.9%, particle size 0.6-1.2 μm) was 1.4 wt% which is very low in comparison with previously reported composite polymer electrolytes. The ionic cond. of a composite polymer electrolyte contg. 1.4 wt% BaTiO3 was 1 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 25°, which is at least one order of magnitude higher than that of the pristine polymer electrolyte (4 × 10-7 S cm-1). The transport no. of the lithium ion in this composite polymer electrolyte was higher than that of the pristine polymer electrolyte. The increase in the cond. and the lithium-ion transport no. is explained on the basis of the spontaneous polarization of the ferroelec. material due to its particular crystal structure. The addn. of BaTiO3 powder greatly enhanced the lithium/electrolyte interface stability.

In order to get poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) films contg. high β-phase content, multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were blended with PVDF. For drawn samples, the content of piezoelec. β-form crystal was increased with MWCNT addn. due to the rapid crystn. rate offered by the nucleating action of MWCNT, but soon reached a plateau. Poling on the drawn samples helps addnl. β-phase formation when the added MWCNT content was less than 0.2 wt%; at this MWCNT amt., almost pure β-phase crystal was obtained. More MWCNT addn. induced depolarization to reduce the β-phase content. Undrawn samples show monotonous increase of β-phase content with MWCNT amt. when subjected to poling.

Polymer Nanofiber-Guided Uniform Lithium Deposition for Battery Electrodes
Liang, Zheng; Zheng, Guangyuan; Liu, Chong; Liu, Nian; Li, Weiyang; Yan, Kai; Yao, Hongbin; Hsu, Po-Chun; Chu, Steven; Cui, Yi

Lithium metal is one of the most promising candidates as an anode material for next-generation energy storage systems due to its highest specific capacity (3860 mAh/g) and lowest redox potential of all. The uncontrolled lithium dendrite growth that causes a poor cycling performance and serious safety hazards, however, presents a significant challenge for the realization of lithium metal-based batteries. Here, we demonstrate a novel electrode design by placing a three-dimensional (3D) oxidized polyacrylonitrile nanofiber network on top of the current collector. The polymer fiber with polar surface functional groups could guide the lithium ions to form uniform lithium metal deposits confined on the polymer fiber surface and in the 3D polymer layer. We showed stable cycling of lithium metal anode with an av. Coulombic efficiency of 97.4% over 120 cycles in ether-based electrolyte at a c.d. of 3 mA/cm2 for a total of 1 mAh/cm2 of lithium.
